channel.title: NYT > Climate and Environment
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Extreme Weather Events Hit Around the World in 2025
item.description: Last year was Earth’s third hottest globally, but temperature is just one measure of climate change’s influence.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Palisades Fire burning along the Pacific Coast Highway early last January.

item.title: E.P.A. to Stop Considering Lives Saved by Limiting Air Pollution
item.description: In a reversal, the agency plans to calculate only the cost to industry when setting pollution limits, and not the monetary value of saving human lives, documents show.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow
item.category: Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs (US)
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.media:description: The change could make it easier to repeal limits on pollutants from coal-burning power plants, oil refineries, steel mills and other industrial facilities.

item.title: Under Trump, U.S. Adds Fuel to a Heating Planet
item.description: The president’s embrace of fossil fuels and withdrawal from the global fight against climate change will make it hard to keep warming at safe levels, scientists said.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Benjamin Rasmussen for The New York Times
item.media:description: America’s greenhouse gas emissions from the burning of coal, oil and gas, which had finally started to decline, rose 1.9 percent after Mr. Trump returned to office.

item.title: China’s Coal Ban Improved Air Quality, but Villagers Are Paying the Price
item.description: China banned the burning of coal for heat around Beijing, but natural gas subsidies have run out, leaving many villagers vulnerable in dangerously cold weather.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents of a village in Quyang County, in northern China, soak up the midday sun to try to warm up and reduce their heating costs.

item.title: The View From Above Antarctica’s Fastest Melting Glacier
item.description: Times journalists were able to get tantalizingly close to the Thwaites glacier, which scientists are hoping to spend weeks studying up close.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: The icebreaker Araon at the Thwaites Glacier in Antarctica on Sunday.

item.title: E.P.A. Moves to Limit States’ Ability to Block Pipelines
item.description: The agency wants to curtail a section of the Clean Water Act that Democratic governors have used to restrict fossil fuel development.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow and Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Paul Ratje for The New York Times
item.media:description: A gas pipeline under construction near Amarillo, Texas, in November.

item.title: Orsted Moves to Save Its U.S, Wind Farm Projects
item.description: Orsted’s C.E.O. says it plans to move quickly to complete a $6.2 billion wind farm off Rhode Island after a judge struck down President Trump’s bid to halt it.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.media:credit: Brian Snyder/Reuters
item.media:description: Revolution Wind is expected to power 350,000 homes in Rhode Island and Connecticut.

item.title: A Scientific Expedition to Antarctica’s Thwaites Glacier Deals With Weather Hiccups
item.description: The clock is ticking. But low clouds have prevented helicopters from moving scientists and gear onto the continent’s fastest-melting glacier.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: U.S. Emissions Jumped in 2025 as Coal Power Rebounded
item.description: The increase in planet-warming emissions came after two years of decline as demand for electricity has been surging.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Charlie Riedel/Associated Press
item.media:description: A coal-fired power plant near Emmett, Kan. Demand for power has started surging in recent years amid a boom in data centers, an upswing of domestic manufacturing and the spread of electric vehicles.

item.title: Camping on a Glacier? Watch Your Step
item.description: Experienced Antarctica guides tell Raymond Zhong, our climate reporter, how they set up camp on the Thwaites Glacier so scientists can measure how fast it’s melting. The biggest safety concern? Crevasses.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong, Chang W. Lee, Christina Thornell, Leila Medina and David Seekamp

item.title: Trump Cuts to Energy Projects in Blue States Were Unlawful, Judge Rules
item.description: The Energy Department canceled $7.5 billion in Biden-era energy spending, largely in Democratic-led states, during last year’s government shutdown.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The cuts were part of a larger effort by the Energy Department to cancel spending for projects like hydrogen fuel hubs, electrical grid upgrades and efforts to reduce methane leaks.

item.title: Judge Blocks Trump Effort to Stop Rhode Island’s Revolution Wind Project
item.description: The ruling means that construction can continue on Revolution Wind, a $6.2 billion project off the coast of Rhode Island, at least for now.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Maxine Joselow
item.category: Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, Regulation and Enforcement
item.media:credit: Brian Snyder/Reuters
item.media:description: Components of the Revolution Wind farm project on a pier in New London, Conn., in September.

item.title: Supreme Court Grapples With Louisiana Coastal Lawsuits Against Oil Companies
item.description: The justices heard arguments over whether oil companies sued by Louisiana could move the cases from state to federal court, a venue thought to be friendlier to corporate interests.
item.dc:creator: Abbie VanSickle and Karen Zraick
item.media:credit: Mario Tama/Getty Images
item.media:description: A Chevron Oronite oil additives manufacturing facility, seen in 2008 in Plaquemines Parish, La.

item.title: Europe and China Take Step to Resolve Dispute on Electric Vehicles
item.description: The European Commission allowed carmakers to volunteer limits on their imports from China instead of paying tariffs, an arrangement that could help Volkswagen.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: Leonhard Simon/Reuters
item.media:description: The Cupra Tavascan, an electric vehicle made by Volkswagen in China, at the Munich auto show in 2023.

item.title: Is Grass-Fed Beef Better?
item.description: The idea of cows grazing in a pasture seems idyllic. We asked experts how their emissions stack up compared to factory farms.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
item.media:credit: Photo by Ruth Fremson/The New York Times

item.title: Supreme Court to Hear Case on Louisiana’s Eroding Coast
item.description: Local governments are suing oil companies over environmental damage. The companies want the suits moved out of state courts, to friendlier venues.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick and Abbie VanSickle
item.media:credit: William Widmer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oil industry infrastructure near Pointe à la Hache in Plaquemines Parish, La.

item.title: Trump Wants Greenland — but He’s Not Alone in the Arctic Tug of War
item.description: For decades, an Arctic archipelago called Svalbard has served as a rare refuge of international cooperation. Those days are over.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman, Sarah Hurtes, Louise Krüger and Emile Ducke
item.media:description: A great power competition is intensifying in the Arctic, and not only for Greenland.

item.title: Billions at Stake in the Ocean as Trump Throttles Offshore Wind Farms
item.description: The Trump administration has repeatedly ordered work to stop on offshore wind farms along the East Coast, pushing at least two projects to the brink of collapse.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow and Brad Plumer
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Cj Gunther/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Components of the Vineyard Wind project in New Bedford, Mass., last March.

item.title: Climate Change Threatens Way of Life for Native American Tribes in Pacific Northwest
item.description: Warming seas and increased flooding threaten a way of life for Native Americans who have called the Pacific Northwest coast their home for generations.
item.dc:creator: Charlotte Dulany
item.media:credit: Grant Hindsley for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Skagit River overflowed its banks in December, flooding communities in Washington state.

item.title: What It Takes to Drill Into an Antarctic Glacier
item.description: Our climate reporter Raymond Zhong meets with Paul Anker, a drilling engineer aboard the icebreaker Araon, to discuss the stakes, preparations and pressure of the mission to drill a hole in the Thwaites Glacier to measure the water beneath.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong, Chang W. Lee, Christina Thornell, Jon Miller, Leila Medina and Stephanie Swart

item.title: Trump’s $100 Billion Venezuela Oil Plan Gets a Cool Reception
item.description: President Trump met with oil and gas executives on Friday in an effort to push them to invest money in Venezuela, a plan many of them are reluctant to embrace.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump during a meeting with energy executives at the White House on Friday. He wants the biggest U.S. and European oil companies to pour at least $100 billion into Venezuela.

item.title: An Up-Close Look at the Thwaites Glacier
item.description: From an icebreaker sailing near the Thwaites Glacier in Antarctica, our photographer has captured the many faces of the ice.
item.dc:creator: Chang W. Lee
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Wary of Investing in Venezuela, Big Oil Heads to the White House
item.description: The amounts of money, time and political uncertainty trouble executives at large Western oil companies, who plan to meet with President Trump on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A statue near the Venezuelan state oil company in Caracas. U.S. energy executives were far from ready to make a commitment when President Trump said they would “spend billions of dollars” in that country.

item.title: The War Over the Weedkiller Roundup Might Be Headed to the Supreme Court
item.description: Bayer has asked the justices to decide whether federal law shields the company from lawsuits over its Roundup herbicide and cancer. Democrats and MAHA activists aren’t happy.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Seth Perlman/Associated Press
item.media:description: The herbicide Roundup, when paired with genetically modified seeds, kills weeds without damaging crops. But some evidence has indicated a link to cancer.

item.title: G.M. Books a $7.1 Billion Loss as It Scales Back E.V. Ambitions
item.description: General Motors said it was writing down the value of battery and electric vehicle factories after changes in federal policy undercut demand.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Brett Carlsen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Battery assembly at a General Motors facility in Spring Hill, Tenn. Electric cars have become more difficult to sell since the elimination of federal tax credits last year.

item.title: Climate Change Has Turned Greenland Into a Target for Trump
item.description: A warming planet has opened up new shipping routes and turned Greenland into a geostrategic asset for the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Claire Brown
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Evgeniy Maloletka/Associated Press
item.media:description: A partially frozen sea just outside Nuuk, Greenland, last year.

item.title: The Icebreaker Araon Stops Near the Thwaites Glacier
item.description: Less than a day after arriving at the ice, we are already up close and personal with the fastest-melting glacier in Antarctica.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Disasters Cost U.S. More Than $100 Billion in 2025
item.description: A record-setting 21 thunderstorm events each caused at least $1 billion in damages, a sign that more people and property are in harm’s way.
item.dc:creator: Scott Dance
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Over half of disaster damage costs last year were related to the wildfires that burned through Los Angeles neighborhoods last January.

item.title: The Scientists Making Antacids for the Sea to Help Counter Global Warming
item.description: The world’s oceans are becoming dangerously acidic. A controversial proposal would raise the pH — by mixing chemicals into the water.
item.dc:creator: Ferris Jabr
item.media:credit: Alexander Coggin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Adam Subhas of the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution in Massachusetts.

item.title: What Is the UNFCCC and Why Is the U.S. Pulling Out?
item.description: The Trump administration said Wednesday that the United States was withdrawing from 66 international agreements, including a major climate change treaty.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Andreas Rentz/Getty Images
item.media:description: The United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, or UNFCCC, is the treaty that sets a legal framework for international negotiations to address climate change.

item.title: Trump Pulls U.S. Out of United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.description: The action could make it more difficult for a future administration to rejoin the Paris climate accord, the agreement among most nations to fight climate change.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta and Lisa Friedman
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump addressing the 80th session of the United Nations General Assembly in New York last year.

item.title: The Icebreaker Araon Reaches the Thwaites Glacier
item.description: After a 12-day crossing, and a hard slog through sea ice, the field work on this Antarctic expedition is ready to start.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: The crew of the Araon began preparing equipment after arriving in the waters in front of the Thwaites Glacier on Wednesday.

item.title: Democrats Seek Answers About Oil Companies’ Knowledge of Trump’s Venezuela Operation
item.description: Democrats demanded information from seven top U.S. oil companies about any meetings with the Trump administration regarding plans to control Venezuela’s oil industry.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mural in Caracas, Venezuela.

item.title: Oil Firms Say Venezuela Owes Them Billions Over Earlier Investments
item.description: Companies like Exxon Mobil and ConocoPhillips say that Venezuela owes them billions of dollars for confiscating their assets two decades ago.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A tanker docked near a refinery in Punto Fijo, Venezuela. The cost of restoring the country’s oil production after decades of decline is expected to be substantial.

item.title: A Closer Look at Sea Ice Encountered on the Way to Antarctica
Our last sunset, for a while.
FEMA Staff Bracing for Dismissal of 1,000 Disaster Workers
item.description: The job cuts expected this month are part of a plan by the homeland security secretary, Kristi Noem, to remake the agency.
item.dc:creator: Scott Dance
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: A FEMA planning document obtained by The New York Times detailed potential cuts of more than 11,500 people from a work force of about 23,000.

item.title: Entering the Frozen Continent
item.description: As the icebreaker heads into the sea ice zone around Antarctica, penguins and seals start to appear. A scientist on the vessel teaches our climate reporter, Raymond Zhong, to identify different kinds of sea ice.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong, Chang W. Lee, Christina Thornell, David Seekamp, Leila Medina and Stephanie Swart

item.title: The Unanswered Questions About Venezuela’s Environmental Future
item.description: The Trump administration has made no secret that it covets Venezuela’s oil reserves. What happens next could have serious implications for the planet.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Petroleos de Venezuela oil rigs on Maracaibo Lake in Cabimas, in the country’s northwest, in 2022.

item.title: Approaching Antarctica, the Icebreaker Araon Encounters Thick Sea Ice
item.description: The sea ice changed completely over the course of a few hours, from disconnected floes to a vast, snow-covered plain.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Optimism About Nuclear Energy Is Rising Again. Will It Last?
item.description: Companies like Kairos Power are building new types of reactors with the encouragement of the Trump administration, but their success is far from assured.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn
item.media:credit: Ramsay de Give for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kairos Power, which is developing a new kind of nuclear reactor, makes many of its parts at a facility in Albuquerque, N.M.

item.title: An Homage to Our Last Sunsets
item.description: A trip to Antarctica at this time of year means a month of no darkness. Our climate reporter Raymond Zhong reflects on one of the last sunsets that he and our photographer Chang W. Lee will experience for some time.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong, Chang W. Lee, Christina Thornell, Leila Medina and Jon Miller

item.title: Entering the Antarctic Sea Ice, and a New World
item.description: After 10 days with only the open ocean and the occasional iceberg at our sides, sailing into the sea ice felt like crossing into a whole new realm.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Why Chevron Could Reap the Biggest Rewards From Venezuela
item.description: The second-largest U.S. oil company, which kept pumping oil in the country after others left, could find it relatively easy to expand its operations if the political conditions there improve.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A refinery in El Palito, Venezuela. Chevron is the only U.S. oil company with federal authorization to export oil from Venezuela.

item.title: Venezuela’s ‘Dirty’ Oil and the Environment: Three Things to Know
item.description: Most of the reserves in the country are extra-heavy oil that’s tough to extract and generates more greenhouse gases.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Flaring at the Amuay refinery in Punto Fijo, Venezuela, in 2021.

item.title: What to Know About Venezuela’s Oil Industry as Trump Plans U.S. Intervention
item.description: Venezuela claims to have more than 300 billion barrels in the ground, but it is only producing about one million barrels a day.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: What did our photographer take to Antarctica? A lot of cables.
The Trump Administration Approved a Big Lithium Mine. A Top Official’s Husband Profited.
item.description: Karen Budd-Falen, the No. 3 at the Interior Department, didn’t disclose a $3.5 million water-rights contract between her husband and the developers of a Nevada mine, records show.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Rick Bowmer/Associated Press
item.media:description: The Lithium Nevada Corp. mining site in 2023.

item.title: Whales Are in Danger in N.Y. Waterways: ‘Like Deer Crossing the Road’
item.description: As conservation efforts make the waters in the New York region more inviting for whales, increasing traffic from ships and boats has contributed to a climbing number of strandings.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Short
item.media:credit: Johnny Milano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Of the 125 strandings of large whales in the region since 2017, nearly half have shown signs of human interference such as broken bones from a vessel strike or wounds from propellers or fishing gear.

item.title: How Chevron Aims to Tap More Oil Below Kazakhstan’s Grassy Plains
item.description: After spending nearly $50 billion to expand the country’s Tengiz oil field, the American oil giant and its partners encounter more uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed and Desiré Van Den Berg
item.media:description: A new oil processing plant at Tengiz, part of a multibillion-dollar expansion that has increased the field’s capacity.

item.title: Behind the Scenes With Our Photographer
item.description: “I have a lot of gear.” Our photographer Chang W. Lee describes how he plans to capture the journey to Antarctica from every angle, including from a long-range drone and a sound-triggered camera designed to capture a calving glacier.
item.dc:creator: Chang W. Lee, Raymond Zhong, Christina Thornell, Kassie Bracken, Sutton Raphael, Leila Medina and Adam Hogan

item.title: An
item.description: Our reporter sends a dispatch from the icebreaker Araon, currently on its way to Antarctica, about the scientists, their work and how he’s battling seasickness.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong

item.title: Your Antarctica Questions, Answered
item.description: Our reporter Raymond Zhong takes a first round of questions about the trip to Antarctica. First up: How can data gathered on the trip tell us how much time is left for the glaciers?
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong, Chang W. Lee, Rebecca Suner, Stephanie Swart and Christina Thornell
